The techniques of string instrument are plucking, bowing, striking, tapping, strumming, and pizzicato.

The gayageum or kayagum (가야금) is a traditional Korean plucked zither with 12 strings, though some more recent variants have 18, 21 or 25 strings. It is probably the best known traditional Korean musical instrument.
Musicians play some string instruments by plucking the strings with their fingers or a plectrum—and others by hitting the strings with a light wooden hammer or by rubbing the strings with a bow.
Orchestra string section include: violin, viola, cello and double bass.
All of the bowed string instruments can also be plucked with the fingers, a technique called "pizzicato".
A wide variety of techniques are used to sound notes on the electric guitar, including plucking, strumming and even "tapping" on the fingerboard.
The body of most string instruments is hollow. Some, however—such as electric guitar and other instruments that rely on electronic amplification—may have a solid wood body.
In musicology, string instruments are known as chordophones.

String instruments can be divided into three groups: Lutes (which support the strings via a neck and bout - guitar, violin, etc), Harps (which contain the strings within a frame) and Zithers (which have the strings mounted on a body, frame or tube - piano, cimbalom, autoharp).

Percussion is commonly referred to as "the backbone" or "the heartbeat" of a musical ensemble.
In jazz and other popular music ensembles, the pianist, bassist, drummer and sometimes the guitarist are referred to as the rhythm section.
A drum kit consists of bass drum, crash cymbal, ride cymbal, floor tom, hi-hat cymbals, snare drum, and tom-tom drums.

Game:VideoGame:Sports:Racing: Subgenres of racing sports video games are arcade-style, simulation racing, kart racing, and futuristic racing.
The characteristics of racing sports video games are based on real-world racing leagues or fantastical settings.
Racing sports video games started at Space Race released by Atari in 1973.
Kart racing games emerged in the 1990s and were popularized by Nintendo's Super Mario Kart, as a popular sub-genre of racing games.
Futuristic racing games are a type of racing game where players use science fiction vehicles, such as sci-fi cars or other sci-fi vehicles, to race against the clock or other vehicles.
On home consoles, futuristic racing games were defined by Nintendo's F-Zero (1990) for the SNES, which spawned the F-Zero series.
Kart racing games have simplified driving mechanics while adding obstacles, unusual track designs and various action elements.

Arcade-style racing games put fun and a fast-paced experience above all else, a key feature of arcade-style racing games that specifically distinguishes them from simulation racing game is their far more liberal physics.

In real racing (simulation racing games) the driver must reduce their speed to take most turns, arcade-style racing games generally encourage the player to "powerslide" the car to allow the player to keep up their speed by drifting through a turn.
Many arcade racing games in amusement arcades frequently use hydraulic motion simulator arcade cabinets that simulate the look and feel of driving or riding a vehicle.
Kart racing games are a more arcade-like experience than other racing games and usually offer modes in which player characters can shoot projectiles at one another or collect power-ups.
In 1988, Namco released Winning Run which became the second highest-grossing arcade game of 1989 in Japan.
Indianapolis 500: The Simulation, designed by David Kaemmer and Omar Khudari, is regarded as the first true auto racing simulation on a personal computer.

The best selling racing sports video games are Mario Kart, F-Zero, Forza Horizon, Gran Turismo, Need for Speed, Crash Team Racing, Assetto Corsa, Forza Motorsport, F1 series, and Project CARS.
The object of the racing sports video game is to drive cars and win all the races in first place.

Because of their excellent sense of smell, Pigs are used to find truffles in many European countries.
The Pig is often called swine or hog.
When used as livestock, pigs are farmed primarily for the production of meat, called pork.
A group of pigs is called a passel, a team, or a sounder.
Pigs have 44 teeth, and the rear teeth are adapted to crushing.

Pigs are one of the most valuable animal models used in biomedical research today, because of their biological, physiological, and anatomical similarities to human beings.
Pigs are considered hypoallergenic, and are known to do quite well with people who have the usual animal allergies.
A well known fact is that pig eats vegetation, roots, fruits, eggs, flowers, leaves, fish, and dead animals.
The gestation (pregnancy) period for the pig is 112 to 120 days.

Suspense is often maintained as an important plot element of the mystery suspense genre. This is done through the use of the soundtrack, camera angles, heavy shadows, and surprising plot twists.

The Closed (or whodunit) mystery conceals the identity of the perpetrator until late in the story, adding an element of suspense during the apprehension of the suspect, as the audience is never quite sure who it is.
The Open mystery (or howcatchem), reveals the identity of the perpetrator at the top of the story, showcasing the "perfect crime" which the audience then watches the protagonist unravel.

Game:VideoGame:RolePlaying:Roguelikes: Subgenres of roguelikes role playing video games are rogue-lite.

The characteristics of roguelikes role playing video games are based on a high fantasy narrative, random dungeon generation, permadeath, use resource management to survive, hack and slash-based gameplay.
Roguelikes role playing video games started at Beneath Apple Manor published by The Software Factory in 1978.
The term "roguelike" derives from the 1980 game Rogue, written by Glenn Wichman and Michael Toy in 1980.
Roguelikes games were popularized among college students and computer programmers of the 1980s and 1990s.
Rogue proved popular with college students and computer researchers at the time, including Ken Thompson and Dennis Ritchie.

Early roguelikes were developed to be played on text-based user interfaces, games used a mix of ASCII or ANSI characters to visually represent elements of the dungeon levels, creatures, and items on the level.

A primary difference between the Mystery Dungeon games and Western roguelikes is the lack of permadeath, in Mystery Dungeon games, player-characters may die or become too injured, resetting their progress to the start of the dungeon, but the games typically provide means to store and recover equipment and other items from the previous run.

The roguelike genre saw a resurgence in Western markets after 2000 through independent developers who created a new subgenre designated "rogue-lite", indie developers began to incorporate roguelike elements into genres not normally associated with roguelikes, creating games that would form the basis of this new subgenre.

Roguelikes role playing video game is a subgenre of role-playing video games characterized by a dungeon crawl through procedurally generated levels, turn-based gameplay, grid-based movement, and permanent death of the player character.
The best selling roguelikes role playing video games are Mystery Dungeon, Slay the Spire, Pokemon Mystery Dungeon, The Binding of Isaac, NetHack, Spelunky and FTL: Faster Than Light.

The object of the roguelikes role playing video game is to explore the dungeon in order of either claiming an item located at the deepest level of the dungeon, or defeating a specific monster that lives on that level.

While most commonly marketed as a child's toy, the action figure has gained widespread acceptance as collector item for adults.
Some action figures are produced and designed on the assumption it will be bought solely for display as a collectible and not played.
One of the most popular action figure lines of the late '80s and early '90s, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles action figures.

The 80's spawned all sorts of popular action figure lines, many based on cartoon series, which were one of the largest marketing tools for toy companies, some of the most successul to come about were Master of the Universe, G.I Joe, Thundercats and Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle.
Adult-oriented figure lines are often exclusive to specific chain stores rather than mass retail.
Popular lines often have figures available exclusively through mail-in offers and comic conventions, which raises their value significantly.
Ploys such as packaging "errors" and "short-packed" figures have also been used by toy companies to increase collector interest.
Glow-in-the-dark paint and plastic have been utilized in various figure collections, particularly those of the early '90s including Ninja Turtles, Swamp Thing, and Toxic Crusaders.
Manufacturers have packaged their actions figures in a number of ways: Window Box, Carded Bubble, PVC and Tube packaging.

Marvel Legends has popularized the "build-a-figure" concept. Each figure of a particular series includes a body part to a larger-scaled figure. This encourages the consumer to purchase every figure of the given series, in order to complete the larger figure.

An action figure is a character toy figurine made most commonly of plastic, and often based upon characters from a film, comic book, military, video game or television program; fictional or historical.
The famous producer of action figure is Hasbro, Mattel, NECA, McFarlane Toys and Palisades.
Action figure is made of a harder plastic resin such acrylonitrile butadiene styrene.

At high levels of badminton play, the sport demands excellent fitness: players require aerobic stamina, agility, strength, speed, and precision.

Game:VideoGame:Simulation:ConstructionMa: Subgenres of construction management simulation video games are city-building, colony management, business simulation and tycoon, life simulation, factory simulation and government simulation.
The characteristics of construction management simulation video games are economic challenges, windowed interface, graphs and analytic tools to understand the game economy.
Construction management simulation video game can be played with single player.
Construction management simulation video games started at SimCity released in 1989.
Economics play a primary role in construction and management simulations, because they allow players to build things while operating within economic constraints.
The player's role, in Construction games, is usually more involved in detailed decisions than a real manager or administrator.

Construction mechanism in Construction and Management games tend to be one of two types: "plan-and-build", where the construction is completed gradually, or "purchase and place", where the construction appears immediately.
Common resources in Construction and Management games include money, people, and building materials.

Resources in Construction and Management games can be utilized in two ways: "construction", where players build or buy things to serve some purpose, or "maintenance", where players must make ongoing payments to prevent loss or decay.
Many Construction and Management games have no victory condition, although players can always lose by bankrupting themselves of resources.

Business simulation, also known as tycoon games, are a sub genre of Construction and Management games that simulate a business or some other economy, with the goal to help make the business financially successful.

Government simulation is a sub genre of Construction and Management that attempts to simulate the government and politics of all or part of a nation, typically include geopolitical situations, the creation of domestic political policies, or the simulation of political campaigns.
Construction management simulation video game is a subgenre of simulation game in which players build, expand or manage fictional communities or projects with limited resources.
The best selling construction management simulation video games are SimCity, Townscaper, Caesar and Cities: Skylines.
The object of the construction management simulation video game is to build something within the context of an ongoing process.

Noise-cancellation technology in headphones was created because of noisy airplane engine.
Headphones were not meant to be portable until Sony released the Walkman, causing a surge in demand for portable headphones.

Travel:Place:Hotel&Resort: The popular hotel activities are massages, tennis, beach volleyball, yoga, golf, swimming, snorkeling, kayaking, and scuba diving.
The importance of hotel is to provide tourists and travelers services such as security, hospitality, food, fun, and entertainment.

The word hotel is derived from the French hôtel (coming from the same origin as hospital), which referred to a French version of a building seeing frequent visitors, and providing care, rather than a place offering accommodation.

The precursor to the modern hotel was the inn of medieval Europe, possibly dating back to the rule of Ancient Rome. These would provide for the needs of travelers, including food and lodging, stabling and fodder for the traveller's horses and fresh horses for mail coaches.
One of the first hotels in a modern sense, the Royal Clarence, was opened in Exeter in 1768.

Most hotel establishments are run by a general manager who serves as the head executive, department heads who oversee various departments within a hotel, middle managers, administrative staff, and line-level supervisors.

International luxury hotels offer high-quality amenities, full-service accommodations, on-site full-service restaurants, and the highest level of personalized and professional service in major or capital cities.
Lifestyle luxury resorts are branded hotels that appeal to a guest with lifestyle or personal image in specific locations.
The popular hotels are Lotte Hotels and Resorts, and Hotel Shilla (신라호텔), Bomun Lake Resort (보문관광단지), Phoenix Island Villa Condo & Club House, Koreana Hotel.
There are different types of hotels including international luxury hotels, lifestyle luxury resorts, upscale full-services hotels, boutique hotels, microstay hotels, timeshare and destination clubs.
Hotel is an establishment that provides paid lodging on a short-term basis which often contain full-sized luxury facilities with full-service accommodations and amenities.
